trial_identification.studytitle: Scapular contribution for the end-range of shoulder range-of-motion- assessment of the throwing shoulder.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Measurement of scapular contribution to the shoulder axial range of motion in overhead throwing athletes and healthy volunteers.

conditions.healthcondition: scapular contribution for the end-range of shoulder axial rotation

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal musculoskeletal and cartilage development and function

interventions.interventions: in a seated position subjects were asked to actively reach the end-range of shoulder axial rotation, on dominant shoulders, they performed three repetitions ovr a period of about 15 minutes. Humeral and scapular 3D positions were recorded by means of an electromagnetic tracking device. each subject was supervised by a physiotherapist. The task had an overall duration of 1 week, 1 hour each day.
interventions.comparator: control group was constituted by 13 subjects and other 13 were handball players, both were subjected to the same kind of electromagnetic evaluation. control group was formed by normal healthy volunteers.

primaryOutcome.outcome: humeral variables (thoracohumeral and glenohumeral angles) by means of an electromagnetic tracking device, this outcome will be used in clinical assessments
primaryOutcome.timepoint: measured only once, during the mentioned trial

primaryOutcome.outcome: scapular variables (upward rotation, internal and external rotation) by means of an electromagnetic tracking device, this outcome will be used in clinical assessments.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: measured only once, during the mentioned trial

primaryOutcome.outcome: sports activity (handball players) by means of sports activity questionnaire, this outcome will be used in clinical assessments.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: measured only once, during the mentioned trial

secondaryOutcome.outcome: shoulder external and internal rotation measured using an electromagnetic tracking device that will be used for clinical assessments
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: all measured only once during the mentioned trial

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: age between 20 and 30 in all hanball players and healthy volunteers. athletes were all handball players

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Faculty of Human Kinetics, Technical University of Lisbon
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Estrada da Costa 1499-002 Cruz Quebrada Dafundo

fundingsource.fundingname: Faculty of Human Kinetics - Technical University of Lisbon
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Estrada da Costa 1499-002 Cruz Quebrada Dafundo

ethicsAndSummary.summary: the purpose of this study was to describe the relative contribution of the scapular motion on the extreme active amplitude of shoulder ER and IR, in throwing athletes.
